description:
Miscellaneous financial and economic data from the during the U.S. Civil War

This is by no means a complete collection of available data, but consists of some datasets that I found or collected for my own research.
title: Civil War (US) Era Financial Market Data

sources.name: Mitchell, Wesley C., 1908. "Gold, Prices, and Wages Under the Greenback Standard." The University Press.
Mitchell, Wesley C., 1903. "A history of the greenbacks: with special reference to the economic consequences of their issue: 1862-65." Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
Ball, Douglas, 1991. "Financial Failure and Confederate Defeat." University of Illinois Press. ISBN: 9780252017551
The Merchants' Magazine and Commercial Review
Burdekin, Richard C.K. and Farrokh K. Langdana, "War Finance in the Southern Confederacy: 1861-1865", *Explorations in Economic History*, 30, pp 352-376
McCandless, George T., Jr. 1996. "Money, Expectations, and the U.S. Civil War" *American Economic Review*, 86.3, pp. 661-671.
Gregor W. Smith and R. Todd Smith (1997). Greenback-Gold Returns and Expectations of Resumption, 1862-1879. The Journal of Economic History, 57, pp 697-717. doi:10.1017/S0022050700019100.

resources.description:
URL's of the "Notes from the Money Market" sections of the *Bankers' Magazine*

In the *Bankers' Magazine* most financial data appeared in tables in a section
titled "Notes from the Money Market". This table contains Google Books URLs to 
each section for volumes 10-20 (1855-1866)
resources.name: bankers_magazine_notes_from_money_market_url

resources.description:
Price data for U.S. bonds and notes from the Merchants Magazine, 1862-1865

These data appear in tables entitled "Prices United States Paper" appearing
in the section "Commercial Chronicle and Review" of the *Merchants' Magazine
and Commercial Review*. 

The Merhcants' Magazine only began quoting prices of US paper in 1862.
resources.name: merchants_magazine_us_paper

fields.description: Name of the bond
Date of the price
Issue from which the price data come.
Google books URL to the source of the data.
Any notes about the data
Price of bond in nominal (paper) dollars. Face value = 100.
Price of bond in gold dollars.

resources.description:
Confederate War News from Burdekin and Langdana (1993)

This is set to +1 for 1863Q3 after Chancellorsville and during Lee's
Maryland campaign, -1 for 1862Q2 (Peninsula Campaign), 1863:4 (Gettysburg and Vicksburg) and 1864:1 (costly battle of Chickamagua).  Their guideline for constructing the dummy was Schwab (1901, ch 9) major 'crises of confidence' in Richmond. The dummy variable is set to 0 in 1864:2 and 1864:3 due to the stalled Overland and Petersburg campaigns and the nomination of McClellan. 

These data extend the original data by setting it to -1 for 1864Q4 and 1865Q1 although the Burdekin and Langdana analysis stops in 1864Q3 due to a lack of data in other variables.
resources.name: burdekin_langdana_1993_war

fields.description: Equal to -1 if the war trend is favoring the Union, +1 if it favoring the Confederacy, and 0 otherwise.

sources.name: Gregor W. Smith and R. Todd Smith (1997). Greenback-Gold Returns and Expectations of Resumption, 1862-1879. The Journal of Economic History, 57, pp 697-717. doi:10.1017/S0022050700019100.

resources.description:
War news and wartime financial news

Events from Smith and Smith (1997), "Table 1: War News" (p. 706) and "Table 2:
Wartime Financial News" (p. 707).

The set of events are constructed from those events mentioned in Mitchell (1903), pt. 2, chapter 3, as influencing the price of gold.
resources.name: events_smith_smith

fields.description: If true, then war or diplomatic news, else financial news
Event identification number. Unique within `war_news`. Same as the row number in the original table.
Event start date
Event end date

If true, then a Union defat, adverse rumor, or news of difficulties in Union finances, such as further issues of greenbacks. If False, then a Union victory, favorable political news, or improvements in Union public finances.

resources.description:
Bond Metadata

Contains issue dates, coupon periods, maturity, cashflow, etc. data about bond issues for which there is price data.

- Many quoted price series may correspond to multiple bond similar issues. 
- Callable bonds (10-40s and 5-20s) have multiple entries, one for a potential call in each year.
- Metadata on state bonds is rather scarce. 
  Sometimes a range of years is known; in which case, there is a bond issue for each year.
  If no range is known, then a bond issue for each potential year is used (based on the empirical distribution of all bonds for which maturity years are known).

The data are an ``object``, with an 
Each bond issue is an ``object`` containting the following entries.

- ``cashflows``: ``object``
  - ``date``: ``array``. Date of cashflow. %Y-%m-%d.
  - ``cashflows``: ``array``. amount of cashflow in gold dollars
- ``interest``: ``number``. Annual interest rate
- ``periods``: ``array``. Each entry is an ``object`` with keys ``month`` and ``day`` for the month and day of a periodic payment.
- ``issue_date``: Date of issue. %Y-%m-%d.
- ``maturity_date``: Date of maturity. %Y-%m-%d.
- ``call``: For callable bonds, ``TRUE`` if a date before maturity, ``FALSE`` if maturity.
resources.name: bond_metadata

resources.description:
Price data for U.S. government and state bonds 1855-1865.

These data appear in tables in the *Notes on the Money Market* section 
of the *Bankers' Magazine* for volumes 10-19. The description of the tables
noted that these were "the highest cash prices offered ... for the Government 
and leading state securities in the market." `June 22, 1864 <http://books.google.com/books?id=lGAmAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA78>`__.

The prices appear are nominal (not gold) dollars, and were dirty prices for the most part.
resources.name: bankers_magazine_state_govt_loans

fields.description: Name of the price series
Date of the price
Date of the issue from which the price data come.
Google books URL to the source of the data.
Volume of Bankers' Magazine from the the data come
Price of bond in paper dollars. Face value = 100
Price of bond in gold dollars

resources.description:
Daily price of greenbacks in gold in New York (1862-1879)
The price of greenbacks comes from Mitchel (1908), which was put in machine format by Willard et. al. and made available on http://eh.net/databases/greenback/. The data here correct several mistakes in that data.
resources.name: greenbacks

fields.description: Date
Daily high price (gold dollars per 100 greenbacks)
Daily low price (gold dollars per 100 greenbacks)

fields.comment: If data are missing, the reason for the missing data, e.g. Sunday or a holiday.

fields.description:
Daily mean price (gold dollars per 100 greenbacks)

The mean is calculated as exp(0.5 * (log(low) + log(high)))

resources.description:
Major military and non-military events of the Civil War

Appendix Tables 2 "Major military events of Civil War" and 3 "Major non-military events of the Civil War" in McCandless (1996), p. 670.

The sources of these events are 

- Pratt, Fletcher. Ordeal by Fire. New York: William Sloane, 1948.
- Catton, Bruce. The Civil War. New York: Fairfax, 1971.
- Guinnane, Timothy W. and Rosen, Harvey S. and Willard, Kristen L, "Turning Points in the Civil War: Views from the Greenback Market. American Economic Review. 1996.
resources.name: events_mccandless

fields.description: Military or non-military event
Event number (unique within military and non-military categories); corresponding to row in the table.
Time period of the event
Event description
Did the event favor the North in the war?
Was there uncertainty about whether the event favored the north?
Source of event was Catton (1971)
Source of event was Pratt (1948)
Source of event was Guinnane et al (1996)
Start date of event
End date of event

resources.description:
Quotes of government, state and city bonds appearing in the text of the "Notes from the Money Market" (1855-1866)

Although quotes for government and state bonds appeared in tables in the "Notes from the Money Market section" often other, presumably less traded, assets were quoted in the text of the section.
resources.name: bankers_magazine_govt_bonds_quotes_in_text

fields.description: Date on the byline of the "Notes from the Money Market" section.
Volume of the Bankers' Magazine
URL to the Bankers' Magazine page of the article in which the quotation appears.
The name of the bond similar to how it appeared in the text.
The name of th issuer of the bond. "US" or the name of the state or city.

fields.descripton: String form of the price. Either a number, or something 100 @ 101 in which the first number is the low or bid price, and the second number is the high or ask price.

fields.description: Low price (in nominal dollars)
High price (in nominal dollars)
Occastionally the Bankers Magazine included ad hoc tables of quotations of bonds not usually quoted. This field is true if the quotation appeared in one of those tables.
Comment
An attempt to match the quotation to specific bond issues. Incomplete and preliminary.

resources.description:
Mitchell's Factors Which Affected the Gold Price of the Currency

The events listed by Mitchell (1903) as having impacts on specie value of greenbacks.
resources.name: mitchell_events

fields.description:
Category of the event.
One of "money supply", "finance", "politics", "foreign affairs", or "war"
Start date of the event (when news reaches the market)

End date of the event (when news reaches the market)
This may be missing if the news is incorporated in one day.
Description of the event
Page in Mitchell (1903) on which the event is described
If true, then the event was good for the Union (rise in the price of currency in gold)
Start date of expenditures period
End date of expenditures period
War department expenditures (millions). This includes a cumulative average of 50 million in 1862, 100 million in 1863, 200 million in 1864, and 313 million in 1865.
Naval department expenditures (millions)
Civil department expenditures (millions)

Public debt servicing (millions). This excludes cancecellation of treasury notes funded into bonds; including interest in the public debt and redemption of call certificates, due bonds, note issues, and the like.
Total expenditures. Equal to `war` + `navy` + `civil` + `public_debt`.

resources.description: For all Annual Reports of the Treasury issued during the Civil War, the dates on which New York markets responded.
resources.name: annual_report_treasury_news

resources.description:
New York market holidays (1860-1879)

The list of holidays largely comes from the days Mitchell (1908). It is extended back to 1860. During this era, the market appears to have been open on Saturdays, and the only regularly observed holidays were Christmas, New Years, Independence Day and sometimes Thanksgiving (after 1862).
resources.name: holidays

resources.name: mitchell_avg_interest_rates_per_month

resources.description:
Daily price of greenbacks in gold in New York (1862-1879) with imputed missing values.

This table uses the data from ``greenbacks`` and fills in the missing observations using a the smoothed values of a local level model.
resources.name: greenbacks_fill

resources.description:
Yield data for U.S. government and state bonds 1855-1865.

For the price series listed in ``bankers_magazine_state_govt_loans``, calculate clean and dirty prices, accrued interest, yields, duration, and maturity.

The price quotations in the original source do not uniquely match a bond issue, so each price series may be matched to multiple bonds.
resources.name: bankers_magazine_state_govt_loans_yields
